title: How many deaths attributed to COVID-19 will have been reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the United Kingdom as of 1 June 2020?
possible_answers: More than 3,000 but less than 5,000 deaths
preds:
The WHO Situation Report for the 09 April 2020 states the UK has had 7097 deaths. 
https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200409-sitrep-80-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=1b685d64_4
More than 7000 since yesterday on worldometer...
Given the current rate of deaths per day, lack of testing, and late implementation of interventions.
UK situation is dire.  If confirmed case rate continues at April pace along with 10.2% fatality (Data: CDC · WHO · ECDC), then 7000 will be eclipsed by end of April—forget June.

There is new distinction between deaths coming into play. Deaths 'with' Covid and deaths 'by' Covid have not yet been recognised by the WHO. If the distinction is picked up we can expect a much lower death rate. I'm not holding my breath.
Unfortunately the death rate continues to grow, I can currently see 20000 deaths by 1st June

The infection recovery rate numbers in the UK is comparatively low against other western countries in EU. Possibly because centralized reporting by National Health Service excludes deaths in other sectors (eg care homes for elderly do not report). The WHO gets its official numbers from the NHS
The death rate is currently around 700-800/day and growing, making me certain that the death toll attributed to the virus will be well above 7,000 by 1st June 2020.
2, currently at 4300 rising by 700 per day with 2 months remaining.

As of April 3rd. 2,921 deaths total for the UK (ECDC). Death rate doubling every 3 days. If death rate would stabilize at the current level (around 380 deaths per day). You will reach 7,000 by the middle of April.....unfortunately.

On current trends, the U.K. fatality rate is doubling every 3 days. This would mean reaching more than 7,000 deaths as early as Monday 6th April or Tuesday 7th at very latest - the lag also means reaching this number of deaths was locked in 3 or so weeks ago (before the nationwide lock-down) and is therefore certainly inevitable by 1st June.
2532 April 2. 58 days to June 1. You would only need to average approximately 80 a day to reach over 7000. They are running about 700 deaths a day now.
Deaths in the US have been around 10% of the total number of cases.
400 a day and have not reached peak yet so likely over 7000.
Assuming UK follows Italy (which it currently does for both infections and deaths), then 7000 will be reached in April.
Current deaths are around 2,300, case doubling rate is between 3 and 4 days, and infected take about 3-5 weeks do die from onset of infection. The curve has not peaked yet.

According to JHU, the number is at 2359.
Model assumes the peak of the curve hasn't been reached yet.
There's enough reason to believe 7000 will be reported around the start to middle of May.
Now taking the view we are between 7-14 days before the peak and even though growth rate on new cases is slowing deaths is increasing.

Logistic model assumes daily death peaks on 29 March and extrapolated to 1 June.
Total deaths by that time are 8800, way above the last basket.

Two highest days of deaths were last two days, incl over 500 today (unofficial). At this rate it will take 12 days to hit 7000 and there are still nearly 2 months until the deadline. Given that the last two days are high points the rate may still be rising rather than constant. Mean daily deaths would have to be ~80 or less for this to miss (a drop of 4X-5X from current numbers). New cases are also rising, but this may be due more to increased testing than increased incidence.  Data from Spain, Germany, and Italy suggest it's unlikely to see a turn around in the death rate in less than 12 days. Anything approaching the current rate for more than a week would require a near halt in deaths to stay below 7000.  Finally, there is some evidence that the official count missed hundreds of deaths at home. Increased accuracy in the count would thus also push the numbers up. A decrease in accuracy would likely only happen due to deliberate undercounting or in the event of a surge.  Basically, we would need either an effective treatment or the discovery of a significant data error for this to stay under 7,000.
200 deaths per day through the end of April equals 7000 deaths...
~2% cases leading to death and expect more than 145k cases

Public support for "stay at home" will Waver as UK weather gets better. Italy has been locked down for 2 0days and cracks are starting to appear in the resolve of the population. If this doesn't materialise it will be because the government has changed policy and eased movement restrictions to placate the population, increasing fatalities.
The current number is 1400, with around 350 a day, we have not yet reached the highest point.
D'oh, got the order of the answers wrong in my first forecast. Correcting.

The United Kingdom TC 19526  NC 2433  TD  1228   ND 209
https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200330-sitrep-70-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=7e0fe3f8_2

There are already more that 1,000 deaths. If deaths carry on at the current rate there will be roughly 12,000 dead by 1 June, so even if we are optimistic and think that the counter measures taken start of have an effect in about 4 weeks, we will already be close to 6,000-7,000 dead. It will only be if the countermeasures have a stronger effect than most experts believe possible that less that 7,000 will die before 1 June.

There are already more that 1,000 deaths. If deaths carry on at the current rate there will be roughly 12,000 dead by 1 June, so even if we are optimistic and think that the counter measures taken start of have an effect in about 4 weeks, we will already be close to 6,000-7,000 dead. It will only be if the countermeasures have a stronger effect than most experts believe possible that less that 7,000 will die before 1 June.

I have been doing some forecasting on reported cases in the UK and applying a 5% death rate.
I believe there will be 135,000 reported cases and between 6500-7000 deaths.
Pessimistic, as the UK took measures quite late in the game.
Impossible to tell yet where the top of the curve will be.
We are running out of doctors and ventilators already in some parts

The UK already has enough cases to result in 7k+ deaths. 7k is 5.7 times what Johns Hopkins is showing today (1,228). UK is currently doubling every 3.5 days. It should break 7k in 9 days, and WHO is usually 1 day behind, so 10 days. Also, Johns Hopkins shows only 151 recoveries. It would seem that nearly all of the confirmed cases that have run their course so far in the UK resulted in death. This could be due to only confirming severe cases. Regardless, the forecast stands.

I suspect they will cross the 7000 threshold by April 10th. Their current rate of growth is approx 25% (using trailing three day average) with a total of 1228. Assuming the rate of growth drops 1% per day we are less than two weeks away from reaching 7000.
My current UK covid-19 model figures that 7000+ deaths will happen around the first week of April - unless their is a large slowdown in % of deaths.

In the best possible scenario, the number of deaths will increase from now, 29 March for just two weeks at a rate of doubling every three days. (Current rate is doubling every 2-3 days, and lockdown may not be stringent enough so it is likely to last longer). Current total is 1,000. Minimum number of doubles is 4, therefore minimum total is 16,000 deaths. I think we will see somewhere nearer 100,000 and probably much more.

UK doubles its numbers each 4 days. By the end of March the figures will exceed 20,000 confirmed cases. . It is however certain that the number of total cases is much higher than the number of known confirmed cases – this is mainly due to asymptomatic transmission (individuals with mild or no reported symptoms are still contagious). By the end-April is expected that the confirmed cases will exceed 300.000. Nevertheless, the growth rate deserves attention since he death toll rises as well.

Updated to round down the likelihood of < 3000 deaths to 0. At current rate, it will exceed that value this week. (Doubling time is currently 3 days). Reduced other values < 7,000 for similar reasons.  Current case count doubling time is 4 days, suggesting that there will be well over 100K cases by June 1 (64 days from now)

There are already more than 1,000 deaths in the UK. It is roughly the size of Italy, which already has more than 10,000 deaths, and ~50 larger than Spain with 6,528 deaths. UK response has been mediocre at best. Confirmed case trends suggest it is tracking a similar growth pattern to Spain and Italy.  Also, the bands for each of the first 4 are quite narrow, reducing the likelihood that the final count will fall into one of them.

There are currently over 1,000 deaths with around 17,000 cases, for a greater than 5% death rate. Because the number of cases will increase quite a bit, more than 140,000, then a 5% mortality rate will be greater than 7,000.

Normal excess mortality rate as a result of seasonal flu in the UK ranges from 11,875 to 28,330. The period from now to June remains within the flu season and given an estimate of 700,000+ cases and a mortality rate of 3%, a figure of close to 20,000 is estimated. Similar to seasonal flu mortality given the extreme lockdown measures undertaken. https://parliamentlive.tv/Event/Index/2b1c71d4-bdf4-44f1-98fe-1563e67060ee
https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/839350/Surveillance_of_influenza_and_other_respiratory_viruses_in_the_UK_2018_to_2019-FINAL.pdf
Strict measures can be effective as seen in south korea. Needs to be revieved as time goes on
On current data, I am looking at 6300 deaths in period, but feel with more testing and reporting on balance the number will go higher. Lockdown impact hopefully will start to show next week

Some estimates have put that the UK will suffer less than 7,000 deaths however that data is based off of China which would make the estimate extremely conservative considering the level of China's lockdown and many other variables. Realistically the number of deaths are doubling every couple days and the peak of cases could be a month from now.
I think no need to explain the situation.
+260 today, total up to 1019, first bin already surpassed.
Altering my opinion having read the imperial college report in todays times , however will review.
updating quite a bit on yesterday's figures, which look more like 2-day doubling at the moment.

Infection is raising, and the delay of contenitive measures can play a crucial role in the mortality rate. NHS is in shortage of personnel, this can be challenging in situation of overuse of hospitals .

imperial college London have said the current trajectory is 5700 deaths with social distancing. 
They expect a peak death rate of 250 before dropping off.  Factors to consider. 
This is is why keep up China Style social distancing, which I do not believe we will do. An article last week by the times said that when GDP drops by 6% in the U.K. as many as 400,000 die. It seems a bad trade and hopefully a conservative government will recognise that.  http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/b910ff90-7062-11ea-ac40-2259b5e452c2

Look at the curves updated daily by the FT at https://www.ft.com/coronavirus-latest
Almost 800 deaths in 15 days, doubling every 2.5 days at current rate. 62 days to go.
It would potentially get to the 5 bucket doubling at every 5 days rate.

Estimating total cases to increase at similar rate for another couple of weeks, then slow as effects of isolation take effect. After a few more weeks there should be the ability to test much more effectively which would reflect increasing numbers through May. Totals could then exceed 200,000 by some margin. Even if the NHS can cope it is still likely to strain for the system, so rate of death at 3% over next two months suggesting that  total deaths could easily reach 7,000.
This is the road Boris has taken...
Research teams around the world have singular focus, expect a vaccine or other similar preventive breakthrough soon

Number of icu beds are lower in uk vs Italy. Assuming a 5% icu rate. Roughly 135000 covid cases. Looking at Italy I am presuming uk will ramp up additional beds quicker. Also China had lower deaths vs Italy despite having a relatively weaker health infrastructure. Though measures by uk have been pretty poor.

They gained 1452 yesterday and about 1400 the day before by WHO situation report but UK health statistics say more like 2100. In looking at curves it appears coronavirus takes 4 to 6 weeks to peak. It looks like two more weeks to peak level. While you could model how many more cases a day before it levels off in two weeks let us say average of 3000. 3000 times 14 is 42000 more cases through April 10th. That leaves about 7 weeks left. The curve starts going down for 4 weeks averaging 1700 new cases a day. 30 days is another 51000 cases. 3 weeks left at 1000 cases a day or 21000 more. 14543 as of today. All added is: 128,543. China’s death rate was about 4% and UK so far looks to be about 5%. Let us go with 5% or 6427. This of course could be much better modeled using a computer but rough estimate is between 6500 to 7500.

See NY time graphs of death rates for various countries.  There are many variables both for and against Covid-19 but until the policies of China and the Italian city of Vo' are copied, I don't see why the rates will change. I estimate the total deaths for the UK by June 1, will be more than 5,000 by May 10, 2020 and above 10,000 by June 1, 2020.
Starting with equal chances averaged against current crowd consensus. Will research further and revisit.

Slightly hesitant to go heavier in on >7000 as stats have been under-reported over the past few days due to supposed issues around family consent. This question does have 67 days to run however, and once you start to get a few days running of >500 deaths it soon mounts up.

Current trend suggests high end of forecast, but lockdown and better testing should stem the tide also, I have also factored in, lockdown ending to early due to economic pressure and seeing a second spike
I am expecting up to 200K cases with 5-10% deaths

Some base stats here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1002636 Additional info: Italy is comparable, with 
8165 deaths recorded to date. Spain at 4145 deaths. Demographics similar to UK.  Almost certain UK will reach 7,000 deaths in 67 days from now.  Queries revolve around effectiveness of social distancing and accurate recording of cause of death and WHO interpretation.

7k is 15.1 times what Johns Hopkins is showing today (465). UK is currently doubling every 4 days. That's 15 days to pass 7k, and 65 days until the deadline. With an average time from symptoms to death of 14 days, there are already, or will soon be, enough people infected to reach 7k. https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_coronavirus_pandemic_cases/WHO_situation_reports
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/coronavirus-death-rate/#days
No reason to expect better that Italy or Spain
